title-group.article-title: Applications of linear differential inclusion-based criterion to a nonlinear chaotic system: a critical review

article-meta.aff: Institute of Maritime Information and Technology, National Kaohsiung Marine University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Global Earth Observation and Data Analysis Center, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Cheng-Wu Chen, Institute of Maritime Information and Technology, National Kaohsiung Marine University, Kaohsiung 80543, Taiwan Email: chengwu@mail.nkmu.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this study we present a neural network (NN)-based approach to represent a nonlinear Takagi–Sugeno system. A linear differential inclusion (LDI) state-space representation is utilized to deal with the NN models. Taking advantage of the LDI representation, the stability conditions and controller design are derived for a class of nonlinear systems. The controller design is based on the fuzzy control and parallel distributed compensation scheme, which is utilized to construct a global fuzzy logic controller by blending all local state-feedback controllers. Furthermore, this control problem can be reduced to linear matrix inequality problems by the Schur Complements. Efficient interior-point algorithms are now available in the Matlab toolbox to solve this problem. A chaotic system is simulated to show the feasibility of the proposed fuzzy controller design approach.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Takagi and Sugeno (1985) first proposed the new concept for fuzzy inference systems, now called the Takagi–Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model, which has been successfully applied in many successful works in industry and academia. This strategy employs linear models in the consequent parts, making it simple to use conventional linear system theory for analysis. Since its inception, a variety of T-S fuzzy model-based controllers have been suggested (Hsiao et al., 2005; Chen et al., 2010, and the references therein). In this type of fuzzy model, the local dynamics in different state-space regions are represented by a set of linear sub-models. The overall model of the system becomes a fuzzy ‘blending’ of these linear sub-models.

In this new and rapidly growing field, the linear matrix inequality (LMI) theory provides a valuable alternative to the analytical method. With it a variety of problems that arise in system and control theory can be reduced to a few standard convex or quasiconvex optimization problems. The resultant optimization problems can be easily solved by a numerical computation. This is what makes the LMI techniques very efficient and practical tools for solving complex control problems (Boyd et al., 1994; Park et al., 2002). Briefly, the fuzzy controller design problem is formulated into solvable LMI problems. The common P matrix of the stability conditions can be obtained by using LMI optimization algorithms to guarantee the stability of the structural systems.

Recently, increasing research activities in the field of structural control have stimulated the development of a variety of control methods. These methods include fuzzy control, optimal control, pole placement, sliding mode control, etc. (see Casciati, 1997; Wang et al., 2002; Lu et al., 2003; Chen et al., 2004, 2009; Chen, 2011, and the references therein). For example, Casciati (1997) proposed the conduction of stability checks in the design of a fuzzy controller for nonlinear structures. In 2002, Wang and Lee developed a method of fuzzy sliding mode control based on the genetic algorithms that guaranteed the stability and robustness of the fuzzy control system. Moreover, advanced techniques in soft computing and artificial intelligence have also been successfully applied to various fields, such as robot manipulation (Hsiao et al., 2005a–e; Chen and Huang, 2011; Chen et al., 2011a,b; Lee et al., 2011; Shih et al., 2011a,b; Chen BS et al., 1997; Chen, 2011e; Chen et al., 2007g; Chen and Chen, 2010c; Chiou et al., 2011; Guo et al., 2004; Lee et al., 2010c; Tanaka and Wang, 2001; Tseng et al., 2011a; Tseng et al., 2011b), engineering applications (Lu et al., 2003; Chen, 2006; Amini and Vahdani, 2008; Chang et al., 2008; Chen et al., 2008d,e; Trabia et al., 2008; Tu et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2008a; Shih et al., 2010b; Yeh and Chen, 2010), architectural engineering (Chen et al., 2004; Hsieh et al., 2006; Chen, 2010a–c; Hsu et al., 2010; Chen, 2011c,d; Chen et al., 2011c,d; Liu et al., 2011; Tang et al., 2011), satellite observations (Lin et al., 2009a,b; Lin and Chen, 2010b; Lin and Chen, 2011; Yeh et al., 2011), marine research (Chen et al., 2005, 2006a–c, 2007a–f, 2008a–c; Chen, 2009b,c; Chen et al., 2009c; Tseng et al., 2009; Chen, 2010d, 2011a–c), network optimization (Chen and Chen, 2010b; Kuo et al., 2010; Shih et al., 2010a,c; Kuo and Chen, 2011a,b; Kuo et al., 2011), system development (Chen, 2009a; Chen et al., 2009a,b,d–f; Chen, 2010c; Chen et al., 2010a,c,d,f; Lin and Chen, 2010a; Shih et al., 2011d; Tseng et al., 2011), educational improvement (Chen et al., 2010b; Shih et al., 2010d; Shen et al., 2011; Shih et al., 2011c) and management of leisure and tourism industries (Tsai et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2008b; Yeh et al., 2008; Yildirim et al., 2009; Zhao et al., 2009; Chen and Chen, 2010a; Chen et al., 2010e,g,h; Chiang et al., 2010; Lee et al., 2010a,b; Tsai and Chen, 2010, 2011).

Many of the network architectures mentioned above were actually developed by researchers who remained active through the lean years of the last two decades. We owe the modern renaissance of neural network (NN) technology to their efforts and persistence. In the last 10 years, we have witnessed substantial growth and breakthroughs in NN research and development. For example, Kim and Inman (2003) developed a direct adaptive NN controller for a model underwater vehicle. They routed a radial basis NN and a multilayer NN in a closed loop to approximate the nonlinear vehicle dynamics. No prior off-line training phase and no explicit knowledge of the structure of the plant are required. This scheme exploits the advantages of both NN control and adaptive control. In the same year, Lin et al. (2003) proposed a benchmark NN approach for the identification and control of a flexible structure: a thin simply supported plate with bonded piezoelectric film actuators and sensors. They developed a specific linear differential inclusion (LDI) for a class of multilayer feedforward networks. With this technique, it is shown that the plant model identified by the NN can be represented as a linear time-invariant system so that traditional or advanced linear control theory can be directly applied to design the stabilizing flexible structure controller. In 2004, Guo et al. presented a NN control method designed for the control of nonlinear dynamic systems subject to random road roughness, which includes an error back-propagation algorithm with quadratic momentum of the multilayer forward NNs (Guo et al., 2004). This method achieved effective on-line NN control of the low-frequency road-induced vibration of the vehicle body and the fast response of the magneto-rheological (MR) damper. The numerical simulations and an experiment with a quarter-size car model indicate that the semi-active suspension with a MR damper and NN control is superior to the passive suspension methods for a low frequency range. Crupi et al. (2004) designed another new procedure, incorporating NNs to evaluate the vibration signatures and recognize the presence of faults.

NNs have replaced the traditional expert systems used in the past for the fault diagnosis, because they are dynamic systems and thus adaptable to continuously variable data. However, the disadvantage of the commonly used NNs is that they need to be trained by real examples for different fault typologies. The innovative aspect of the new procedure discussed in this work is that it allows us to diagnose faults that are not considered in the training set. In 2005, Li et al. developed a genetic algorithm-based back-propagation NN suboptimal controller to control vibration in a nine-degree-of-freedom modular robot (Li et al., 2005). They used a finite-element method to model the robotic modules. All the system dynamics equations were established using the substructure synthesis method. The joint stiffness parameters could then be identified based on experimental modal analysis. After modeling the whole structure, including the robotic modules and the joint parameters, simulations of the vibration control for the modular robot in several configurations were carried out. In the same year, De Melo et al. (2005) developed an intelligent forecast system consisting of three units: a main unit comprised of a multilayer NN; a second unit based on fuzzy logic, which was used to prepare the data; and a third unit based on a genetic algorithm, used to determine the best set of data to be analyzed. The data were set up using a strategy that classifies the terms of the series into parts with the same quantity of elements. Rao and Datta (2005) presented an efficient generalized control scheme using a solo NN controller (microcontroller) for the predictive single mode response control of building frames subjected to earthquake excitation. The control scheme was developed by considering the time delay that exists between the measurement of the response and the actual application of the control force. The microcontroller was trained to provide the control force for target reduction for any building frame ranging between 5 and 15 stories. The efficiency of the control scheme was demonstrated by controlling the first mode response of the frame when subjected to stresses using data taken from the El Centro and Treasure Island earthquake records. In 2006, a NN was designed to compute incremental changes in the reference values of the joint angles to achieve successful tip tracking in the operational space. In this method, tip positioning errors in the x- and y-directions are utilized as inputs to the NN. The cost function, which is minimized in training the NN, is also chosen to be the sum of the squares of the tip positioning error in both directions. Joint angle control is provided by a proportional-derivative (PD) controller. Simulations were carried out to evaluate the performance of the NN-based trajectory tracking method, and the results depicted in both joint and operational spaces (Oke and Istefanopulos, 2006). Yang et al. (2006) also presented a NN design for system identification and vibration suppression in a building structure with an active mass damper. They showed both numerically and experimentally that the NN controller could reliably identify system dynamics and effectively suppress vibration. In the experimental model, which has a fundamental frequency of about 0.96 Hz, the steady-state vibration amplitude under resonance and random excitation are reduced by 80% and 70%, respectively. The controller is also shown to be robust to variations in system parameters. In 2008, they proposed a particle swarm optimization (PSO) method for tuning of the fuzzy proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller, in which the centers and the widths of the Gaussian membership functions, the number of fuzzy control rules and the PID gains are all parameters to be determined simultaneously. Meanwhile, based on the concept of multiobjective optimization, Ko and Wu (2008) discussed ways of defining the fitness function of the PSO to include different performance criteria. The state of the art of physical-principle-enhanced hybrid artificial neural network (ANN) modeling has been advanced by the development of network configurations with parallel modules reflecting the structural information of the physical principles (Cao et al., 2008). The parallel module NN configuration has been applied to develop a scalable and invertible dynamic MR fluid damper model.

To address issues encountered with the current ANN-based MR damper models found in the literature, two ANN-based MR damper models are developed in this study. The network training/testing results indicate that while both models provide satisfactory performance, the parallel modular neural network (PMNN) model outperforms the baseline model, showing superior control-input-output scalability. In 2009, Yildirim et al. (2009) presented an experimental design method for noise and vibration analysis of two car engines by feedforward and radial basis NNs. They experimentally analyzed two types of car engines by using an intelligent data acquisition card with suitable software. They used the measured vibration and noise parameters for the two car engines as the desired values in the NNs. The effectiveness of the radial basis neural network (RBNN) with the back-propagation algorithm for predicting the vibrations and noise of the two car engines is demonstrated. The robustness of the proposed RBNN predictor for the parameters of vibration and noise, as well as measurement disturbances, is also investigated. In the same year, Chang (2009) presented a neural-based algorithm that could cancel out the nonlinear narrowband and broadband noise in an active noise control (ANC) system. The improved method, including ways to decide the learning rate and optimal initial weighting values of the NN, was presented to enhance the noise reduction performance. The proposed approach does not need the mathematical transfer functions of the duct plant and also provides a method to avoid the premature saturation problem of NNs. A comparison with conventional neural methods by a simulation showed that the proposed method could effectively cancel out undesired noise. Ji et al. (2009) also presented an improved active noise isolation method, consisting of a self-sensing actuator (SSA), a NN identifier and an adaptive feedback controller using a finite impulse response (FIR) filter and the Filtered-X least-mean square (LMS) algorithm, in which no acoustical sensors were necessary to suppress the noise transmission through a plate structure. The structure consisted of a composite plate with an embedded piezoelectric patch. A bridge circuit was used to separate the sensor signal from the actuator signal on the piezoelectric patch and the obtained signal was used in the identification of the sound pressure of a point in space. A NN was used instead of Rayleigh's integral formula for identification of the sound pressure, as in the former study. The results show that the proposed control approach, using both a SSA and NN identifier, exhibited better noise control performance than did Rayleigh's integral formula. The adaptive fuzzy sliding mode (AFSM) control algorithm has been adopted to actively control nonlinear structural vibration (Li et al., 2010). Since the full state feedback of the structure is needed for the AFSM control algorithm, a dynamic neural network (DNN) observer has been proposed to consider the nonlinearity of the structure. The NN weights are thus adapted on-line, with no off-line learning being required. Furthermore, no exact knowledge of structural nonlinearities is needed. The weight-training algorithm is established based on Lyapunov stability theory in the presence of modeling error. A semi-active control algorithm is used for a MR damper to track the active control force, which is computed by the AFSM control algorithm based on the DNN observer. Results of the numerical simulation of semi-active control for a 20-story nonlinear building using MR dampers was carried out to verify the performance of the DNN observer and the effectiveness of the proposed AFSM control. Lee et al. (2010) focused on the development of triangular fuzzy numbers, the revising of triangular fuzzy numbers and the constructing of a half-circle fuzzy number (HCFN) model, which can be utilized to perform more plural operations. They further transformed for trigonometric functions and polar coordinates. From HCFNs, we can conceive cylindrical fuzzy numbers, which work better in algebraic operations. An example of fuzzy control is simulated to show the applicability of the proposed HCFNs. Fu et al. (2010) proposed annealing robust radial basis function networks (RBFNs) based on support vector regression (SVR), RBFNs and the annealing robust learning algorithm (ARLA) for nonlinear inverse system identification with outliers. They applied the proposed approach to MR damper systems. Simulation results showed the superiority of the proposed method for the prototype MR damper and the nonlinear inverse system identification with outliers. In 2011, Lin et al. proposed the use of Fuzzy Lyapunov Stability Analysis and NN Modeling for Tension Leg Platform (TLP) Systems (Lin et al., 2011). In that work, some mathematical formulations for TLP systems are first reviewed. Then, the NN model is employed to represent a TLP system, which is done via the back-propagation algorithm. Meanwhile, a LDI state-space representation is utilized to construct the dynamics of the NN model. The LDI equation is similar to a T-S fuzzy system but makes it easier to analyze the stability of the controlled systems. A parallel distributed compensation (PDC) scheme, combined with an H-infinity control design, is proposed to achieve control performance and to ensure the stability of TLP systems subjected to an external wave force. In terms of the stability analysis, the LMI conditions guaranteeing the stability of the TLP system are derived from fuzzy Lyapunov theory.

However, to the best of our knowledge, in relation to the NN model, the application of LDI-based stability analysis for a chaotic system has been seldom discussed. How to deal with stability analysis, as well as stabilization problems, for nonlinear systems when using an NN-based approach needs further discussion. For this reason, we propose a NN-based approach and design a LDI state-space representation to deal with the stability analysis of NN models. The LDI representation allows us to design a state-feedback controller for the dynamics approximating NNs. A fuzzy model-based controller is designed based on the LDI formula. Control is achieved via a LMI condition derived in terms of the Lyapunov theory. We combine the T-S fuzzy model-based control approach with the NN-based approach to obtain a simple and practical control scheme, then use this scheme to successfully achieve the desired stabilization performance for nonlinear systems.

This rest of the study is organized as follows. Firstly, the T-S type fuzzy model is briefly presented and the NN approximation is reviewed to model the structural systems. Then, based on the LDI representation and Lyapunov's approach, a stability criterion is derived to guarantee the stability of fuzzy systems via the LMI technique. Finally, a chaotic system is simulated to demonstrate the efficiency of the method and the accuracy of the results, and conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: 2. Equations of motion for structural systems
sec.p: Assume that the equation of motion for a shear-type building modeled as an n-degree-of-freedom system controlled by actuators and subjected to external force ϕ(t) can be characterized by the following differential equation: (1)M¯··X(t)+C¯·X(t)+KX¯(t)=BU(t)-Mr¯φ(t), where X¯(t)=[x¯1(t),x¯2(t)…x¯n(t)]∈Rn is an n-vector; ¯··X(t),¯·X(t),X¯(t) are the acceleration, velocity and displacement vectors, respectively; matrices M, C and K are the (n×n) mass, damping and stiffness matrices, respectively; r¯ is an n-vector denoting the influence of the external force; B is an (n×m) matrix denoting the locations of m control forces; ϕ(t) is the excitation with an upper bound φup(t)≥ |φ(t) |; and U(t) corresponds to the actuator forces (generated by an active tendon system or an active mass damper, for example). It should be noted that this is only a static model.

For the controller design, the standard first-order state equation corresponding to Equation (1) is obtained by (2)X·(t)=AX(t)+BU(t)+Eφ(t), where (3)X(t)=[x¯(t)¯·x(t)],A=[0I-M-1K-M-1C],B=[0M-1B¯],E=[0-r¯] in which X(t) is a 2n state vector; A is a 2n×2n system matrix.

sec.title: 3. Modeling of the neural network
sec.p: In recent years, NN control techniques have been widely used in nonlinear fields due to their universal approximation capability. Details concerning their successful applications can be found in various sources (see, for example, Luan et al., 2010, and the references therein). A NN-based approach is utilized in the discussion of the stability of nonlinear systems to approximate the nonlinear structural system and the stability conditions thus derived. A NN model has S layers. Each layer has Rσ (σ=1,2,…,S) neurons, in which x1(t) ~xδ(t) and u1(t) ~um(t) are the input variables. The notation Wσ denotes the weight matrix of the σth (σ=1,2,…,S) layer. The transfer function vector of the σth layer is defined as (4)Ψσ(v)≡[T(v1)T(v2)···T(vRσ)]T, where T(vς)(ς=1,2,…,Rσ) is the transfer function of the ς th neuron and v is the net input. The final output of the NN model can then be inferred to be (5)X·(t)=ΨS(WSΨS-1(WS-1ΨS-2 (······Ψ2(W2Ψ1(W1Λ(t)))······))), where ΛT(t)=[XT(t)UT(t)],
with XT(t)=[x1(t)x2(t)…xδ(t)], UT(t)=[u1(t)u2(t)…um(t)].

Although there have been many successful applications of NNs, there are still some drawbacks to their use in any control scheme. Most notably, guaranteeing stability becomes a major problem. Recently, a class of NNs that admit a LDI state-space representation has been proposed and used in stability analysis with a Lyapunov function method. Some systematic model-based NN control design techniques have been developed based on the LDI model. A LDI state-space representation is adopted below in order to derive the LMI inequality and deal with the stability problems (Luan et al., 2010).
Definition 1 (Boyd et al., 1994; Limanond and Si, 1998; Hsiao and Hwang, 2003; Hsiao et al., 2008) A LDI system can be described in the state-space representation as (6)Y·(t)=A(a(t))Y(t),A(a(t))=∑i=1 rhi(a(t))A¯i, where r is a positive integer; a(t) is a vector signifying the dependence of hi(·) on its elements, that is, hi(a(t))≡hi(a1(t),a2(t)…,an(t)), a(t)=[a1(t),a2(t),…,an(t)]T (in general, a(t) coincides with the state vector X(t)); A¯i (i=1,2,…,r) are constant matrices; and Y(t)=[y1(t)y2(t)…yj(t)]T.
Remark 1: The class of the structural system (2) can be regarded as a kind of LDI (Boyd et al., 1994). The properties of LDI mean that, without loss of generality, we can use hi(t) instead of hi(a(t)). We will use hi(t) from now on. This class also contains Takagi and Sugeno’s fuzzy model (Takagi and Sugeno, 1985), which is commonly used in the field of fuzzy control.

To begin with, notice that the output T(v) satisfies g1v≤T(v)≤g2v,v≥0, g2v≤T(v)≤g1v,v<0, where g1 and g2 are finite, and indicate the minimum and the maximum of the derivative of T(v), respectively, that is (7)g(T(v))={g1=minvdT(v)dvg2=maxvdT(v)dv. Subsequently, the min–max matrix Gς σ can be defined as follows: (8)Gς σ=diag[g(T(vς))],σ=1,2,…,S;ς=1,2,…,Rσ. According to the interpolation method and Equation (5), we can obtain X·(t)=[∑ςS=1 2hςS(t)Gς S (WS [··· [∑ς2=1 2hς2(t)Gς 2 (W2 [∑ς1=1 2hς1(t)Gς 1(W1Λ(t)) ] ) ]… ] )] (9)=∑ςS=1 2…∑ς2=1 2∑ς1=1 2hςS(t)…hς2(t)hς1(t)Gς SWS …Gς 2W2Gς 1W1Λ(t)=∑ΩσhΩσ(t)EΩσΛ(t), where ∑ςσhςσ(t)≡∑q1 σ=1 2∑q2 σ=1 2···∑qRσ σ=1 2hq1 σ(t)hq2 σ(t)···hqRσ σ(t) forσ=1,2,…,S;hqς σ(t)∈[0 1],∑qς σ=1 2hqς σ σ(t)=1 forς=1,2,…,Rσ;EΩσ≡Gς SWS···Gς 2W2Gς 1W1,∑ΩσhΩσ(t)≡∑ςS=1 2…∑ς2=1 2∑ς1=1 2hςS(t)…hς2(t)hς1(t). Finally, based on Equation (6), the dynamics of the NN model (9) can be rewritten as the following LDI state-space representation: (10)X·(t)=∑i=1 rhi(t)E¯iΛ(t), where hi(t)≥0; ∑i=1 rhi(t)=1; r is a positive integer; and E¯i is a constant matrix with an appropriate dimension associated with EΩσ. The LDI state-space representation (10) can be further rearranged as follows: (11)X·(t)=∑i=1 rhi(t){AiX(t)+BiU(t)}, where Ai and Bi are the partitions of Ei corresponding to the partition Λ(t).

Based on the above modeling schemes for the NN-based approach, the nonlinear structural system (2) can be approximated as a LDI representation (11). That is, a LDI state-space representation for a class of NNs is established. Then, based on this LDI representation, sufficient conditions will be presented to guarantee the closed-loop system finite-time stabilization and eliminate the effect of the approximation errors and external disturbances on the regulated output. These conditions can be reduced to feasibility problems involving LMIs. Moreover, the LDI representation follows the same rules as the T-S fuzzy model, thereby combining the flexibility of fuzzy logic theory and the rigorous mathematical analysis tools of a linear system theory into a unified framework. Tanaka and Sugeno (1992) proposed a control concept called PDC for the fuzzy control of T-S fuzzy systems. The method of fuzzy model-based control via PDC schemes is thus developed to achieve suitable control performance, taking into consideration stability analysis of a nonlinear system. A useful remark is described below.
Remark 2 (Luan et al., 2010): The class of NN-based LDI representations is similar to T-S’s fuzzy model, obtained by interpolating several literalized systems at different operating points through fuzzy certainty functions. Therefore, the results presented above can be applied to their fuzzy models.

sec.title: 4. Linear differential inclusion-based stability conditions for nonlinear systems
sec.p: In this study the PCD technique is adopted in order to design a global controller for the model (11). The ith rule of the fuzzy logic controller (FLC) can be obtained as follows:
Control Rule i: IF x1(t) is Mi1 and…and xg(t)is Mig (12)U(t)=-KiX(t),(i=1,2,…,r), where Ki is the local feedback gain vector in the ith subspace.

The final model-based fuzzy controller is analytically represented by (13)U(t)=-∑i=1 rwi(t)KiX(t)∑i=1 rwi(t)=-∑i=1 rhi(t)KiX(t). The overall closed-loop fuzzy system can be obtained as follows: (14)X·(t)=∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t)[(Ai-BiKl)X(t)]+Eiφ(t).

Therefore, Equation (10) is the control system for structural system (1) obtained via the T-S fuzzy representation and the technique of PDC control.
Definition 2 (Lu et al., 2003): LMI formulation of the design specifications.
The LMI is any constraint of the form (15)F(v)=F0+∑i=1 mviFi>0, where v=[v1,v2,…,vm]∈Rm is the variable vector and the symmetric matrices Fi=Fi T∈Rn×n,i=0,…,m, are given. It can be shown that the solution set {v|F(v)>0} may be empty, but it is always convex. Thus, although (15) has no analytical solution in general, it can be solved numerically by efficient numerical algorithms. Many control problems can be reformulated into LMIs and solved efficiently by recently developed interior-point methods (Boyd et al., 1994).

According to Equation (2), the Lyapunov function of the nonlinear system without the input of the PDC fuzzy control is a linear system. Moreover, Equation (2) is represented by the NN model with PDC fuzzy control in Equation (14). The resulting controlled system, which is a fuzzy ‘blending’ of each individual linear controlled system, is nonlinear. Below, we have to reformulate the controller design problem to solve a LMI problem based on the Lyapunov direct method and Schur Complement representation.

A typical stability condition for fuzzy system (11) is proposed here as follows.
Theorem 1: The equilibrium point of the fuzzy control system (11) is largely stable if there exist a common positive definite matrix P and feedback gains K such that the following two inequalities are satisfied (Chen, 2006; Yeh et al., 2008; Chen, 2010): (16)(Ai-BiKi)TP+P(Ai-BiKi)+1η2PEiEi TP<0 and (17)((Ai-BiKl)+(Al-BlKi)2)TP +P ((Ai-BiKl)+(Al-BlKi)2 ) +1η2PEiEi TP<0, with P=PT>0, for i<l≤r and i=1,2,…,r.
The LMI: (18)[Q(x)S(x)S(x)R(x)]>0, where Q(x)=QT(x), R(x)=RT(x) and S(x) depends on x and is equivalent to (19)R(x)>0,Q(x)-S(x)R-1(x)ST(x)>0.
In other words, the set of nonlinear inequalities (19) can be represented as the LMI (18).

Remark 3: Theorem 1 can be reformulated into the LMI problem (20) and (21). Efficient interior-point algorithms are now available in the Matlab toolbox to solve this problem: (20)Yi+Yi T+1η2EiEi T<0 and (21)Yil+Yil T+1η2EiEi T<0.
Remark 4: Theorem 1 states that the stability of a T-S fuzzy model can be achieved by finding a common symmetric positive definite matrix P for r subsystems. The stability analysis is reduced to solving an eigenvalue problem using the interior-point method associated with LMI techniques. This stability condition can be reduced to that of linear systems when r = 1.

sec.title: 5. A simulation example
sec.p: This problem is of interest, because the Duffing system is a chaotic system, while the van der Pol oscillator produces a stable limit cycle. The Duffing equation can describe a mechanical system with a hardening spring and can display rich nonlinear phenomena, such as chaos and bifurcation. As a result, in recent years, the Duffing equation has become a test bed for various advanced nonlinear and/or adaptive control techniques (Sun, 2010). In this section, the proposed methodology is illustrated for a simulated chaotic system in which the Duffing equation is considered for a large displacement when the high order term cannot be ignored. The chaotic system used in this example to verify the effectiveness of the control system is taken from Hsaio et al. (2005), but the parameters are somewhat different. The objective is to design a fuzzy controller such that the simulated nonlinear chaotic system (22) is uniformly ultimately bounded: (22){x·1(t)=2.5x2(t)x·2(t)=-(0.4x1(t))3-0.4x1(t)-0.01x2(t) +0.4cos(1.29t)+fu(t) where u(t) denotes the control force and f denotes the constant coefficient of the control forces.

Equation (22) is a ubiquitous model that arises in many physics and engineering contexts, such as the study of oscillations of a rigid pendulum undergoing moderately large amplitude motion, vibrations of a buckled beam and so on (Feng, 2006). There exist many sets of harmonic solutions in a chaotic system. When a given initial condition produces a chaotic solution, then an arbitrary initial condition will make the state of a nonlinear system chaotic. In chaos, the system output is extremely sensitive to the initial conditions. Figure 1 shows the responses of the system with no control force, corresponding to two almost identical initial conditions, namely x1(0)=0.175, x2(0)=-1.2 (blue line) and x1(0)=0.176, x2(0)=-1.21 (red line). Figure 2 shows the state behavior for two different initial conditions, namely x1(0)=1.175, x2(0)=-1.2 (blue line) and x1(0)=1.176, x2(0)=-1.21 (red line). From Figures 1 and 2, we know that the chaotic system is sensitive to the initial conditions and may be not chaotic if the initial conditions are different. Figure 3 shows the phase-plane trajectory of the same simulation results with x1(0)=0.175, x2(0)=-1.2. This figure shows us that although the chaotic behavior will be unpredictable, the vibration will in a specific area. Figure 1.
Chaotic behavior of a nonlinear system with no control force (color online only). Figure 2.
Behavior of a nonlinear system with no control force (different initial condition; color online only). Figure 3.
Phase-plane trajectory of the chaotic system.

Nevertheless, the question remains, how do we design a kind of fuzzy controller for nonlinear chaotic systems based on the LDI-based criterion? The basic idea of the proposed approach is to construct a PDC fuzzy controller for dynamic systems with disturbances. The detailed process can be divided into the following steps.

Step 1: Firstly, the NN-based approach is employed to represent the dynamics of the chaotic system. The following neuron transfer functions are chosen: T(vς 1)=21+exp(-vς 10.5)-1,T(vς 2)=21+exp(-vς 20.5)-1,ς=1,2 We can obtain the connection weighting values via repeat learning as described in Equations (5)–(10).
Step 2: In order to stabilize the chaotic system, two model-based fuzzy controllers are designed, based on the concept of the PDC scheme, as displayed below:
Rule 1: IF x1(t) is M11 Rule 2: IF x1(t) is M21
THEN u(t)=-K1x(t), THEN u(t)=-K2x(t).

The membership function for PDC control is plotted in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Membership of the chaotic system.

Steps 3: For the purpose of fulfilling the stability conditions of the theorem, we can obtain the positive definite matrices P and Ki with η=0.3 by using the LMI optimization algorithms from the Matlab toolbox (for more details on finding common solutions in LMI form, see Chen et al. (1999) and Boyd et al. (1994)):

Furthermore, the simulation results for the chaotic system are illustrated in Figure 5, with x1(0)=0.175, x2(0)=-1.2. The control force is shown in Figure 6. From Figures 5 and 6, we know the dynamic system is uniformly ultimately bounded and that this means that the state has achieved stability for Definition 1 by the harmonic control force. Figure 5.
State response of the chaotic system. Figure 6.
Control force of the chaotic system.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: This study is concerned with the stability problem for a nonlinear system represented by a NN-type fuzzy model. In the design procedure, the nonlinear system is represented as a family of NN models. A LDI representation and global FLC is constructed by blending all such local state-feedback controllers. A stability criterion is proposed in terms of Lyapunov's direct method to guarantee the stability of the nonlinear system. Based on this criterion, the fuzzy controller design, with the LMI technique, can be used to stabilize the proposed fuzzy systems.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are also most grateful for the kind assistance of Prof Ali Nayfeh, Editor of the Journal of Vibration and Control, and for the constructive suggestions from the anonymous reviewers, all of which has led to the making of several corrections that have greatly helped us to improve the presentation of this paper.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Science Council of the Republic of China, Taiwan (Contract Nos. NSC 100-2221-E-022-013-MY2, NSC 100-2628-E-022-002-MY2 and NSC 98-2221-E-366-006-MY2).
